title: You can grow new brain cells. Here's how - Sandrine Thuret

multiple-choice.question: Can adults grow new nerve cells?

options.label: A
options.text: No, adults do not grow new nerve cells.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, adults can grow new nerve cells through a process called neurogenesis.

options.label: C
options.text: It's still unclear if adults can grow new nerve cells.

options.label: D
options.text: Only children can grow new nerve cells.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the hippocampus in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: It is responsible for regulating body temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: It is responsible for controlling blood pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: It is involved in learning, memory, mood, and emotion.

options.label: D
options.text: It is responsible for regulating appetite.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of stress on neurogenesis?

options.label: A
options.text: Stress increases the production of new neurons in the hippocampus.

options.label: B
options.text: Stress has no effect on neurogenesis.

options.label: C
options.text: Stress decreases the production of new neurons in the hippocampus.

options.label: D
options.text: Stress increases the survival of new neurons in the hippocampus.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of a high-fat diet on neurogenesis?

options.label: A
options.text: A high-fat diet increases the production of new neurons in the hippocampus.

options.label: B
options.text: A high-fat diet has no effect on neurogenesis.

options.label: C
options.text: A high-fat diet decreases the production of new neurons in the hippocampus.

options.label: D
options.text: A high-fat diet increases the survival of new neurons in the hippocampus.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of running on neurogenesis?

options.label: A
options.text: Running decreases the production of new neurons in the hippocampus.

options.label: B
options.text: Running has no effect on neurogenesis.

options.label: C
options.text: Running increases the production of new neurons in the hippocampus.

options.label: D
options.text: Running decreases the survival of new neurons in the hippocampus.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem that the secret agents face in Dr. Schr√∂dinger's lair?

options.label: B
options.text: Add 5, Add 7, and Take the Square Root

options.label: C
options.text: Subtract 2, Multiply 3, and Divide 4

options.text: Add 1, Subtract 2, and Multiply 5

options.text: They need to avoid entering a non-whole number.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They take the square root of the display number until they reach 2.

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the final step that the secret agents take to reach the number 14 on the control panel?

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They add 5 to reach 7, then add 7 to reach 14.

title: Lessons from the longest study on human development - Helen Pearson

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The Family Dynamics Study

options.label: D
options.text: The Parenting Study

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That poverty has no lasting impact on children's lives

options.label: C
options.text: That children who have a tough start in life are more likely to struggle on almost every score

options.label: D
options.text: That children who are born into wealthy families are guaranteed to succeed

options.label: C
options.text: Having engaged, interested parents who talk and listen to their children

options.label: C
options.text: That the study has to take genes into account when trying to understand the causes of outcomes

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what type of jobs are in high demand at companies like Google, Apple, and Facebook?

options.label: A
options.text: Technical jobs, such as engineering and programming.

options.label: B
options.text: Non-technical jobs, such as marketing, design, and project management.

options.label: C
options.text: Jobs that require a specific degree or certification.

options.label: D
options.text: Jobs that are only available to people with a certain level of experience.

title: Can you solve the wizard standoff riddle? - Daniel Finkel

multiple-choice.question: In a deadly duel against two rival magic schools, a powerful sorcerer from the Newt-niz school wields a wand that can turn people into fish, but his spell only works 70% of the time. What is the success rate of the sorcerer's spell?

If you take the Gaussian wand, which turns one target into a tree and works 80% of the time, what is the probability that you will be turned into a fish immediately after transforming the enchantress?
According to the transcript, what is the best strategy to have the greatest chance of winning the duel?

options.label: A
options.text: Take the Noether 9000 wand and try to win against both opponents.

options.label: B
options.text: Take the Gaussian wand and try to transform the enchantress.

options.label: C
options.text: Take the Bannekar wand and miss on purpose to create a situation where the sorcerer has to try to turn the enchantress into a fish.

options.label: D
options.text: Pass the duel and let the other two opponents fight each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability that you will all be turned into cats if everyone's still standing at the end of the first round?
What is the success rate of the Bannekar wand, which binds one target with vines and casts effectively 60% of the time?

title: Why do I have to use a number 2 pencil?

multiple-choice.question: Why do test instructions often specify the use of a number 2 pencil?

options.label: A
options.text: Because number 2 pencils are the most durable and long-lasting.

options.label: B
options.text: Because number 2 pencils are the most expensive and exclusive.

options.label: C
options.text: Because number 2 pencils make marks that are just dark enough to be sensed by the machine, but also light enough to be erased without leaving a readable mark.

options.label: D
options.text: Because number 2 pencils are the most aesthetically pleasing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason behind the development of machines that could score tests automatically?

options.label: A
options.text: To make grading easier and faster for teachers.

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the workload of administrators.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a more efficient and accurate way of scoring tests.

options.label: D
options.text: To replace human graders with machines.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between the graphite in number 2 pencils and other types of pencils?

options.label: A
options.text: The graphite in number 2 pencils is softer and darker.

options.label: B
options.text: The graphite in number 2 pencils is harder and lighter.

options.label: C
options.text: The graphite in number 2 pencils is better at blocking light than many inks.

options.label: D
options.text: The graphite in number 2 pencils is more expensive than other types of pencils.

multiple-choice.question: Why are number 2 pencils still recommended for use in exams, even though modern scoring machines can detect almost any type of mark?

options.label: A
options.text: Because number 2 pencils are the most convenient and accessible option.

options.label: B
options.text: Because number 2 pencils are the most reliable and consistent option.

options.label: C
options.text: Because number 2 pencils are still the safest option to use, in case the scoring machine is not advanced enough.

options.label: D
options.text: Because number 2 pencils are the most cost-effective option.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the number 2 label on pencils is used in the United States, while other countries use a different system?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the number 2 label is more aesthetically pleasing.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the number 2 label is a more accurate representation of the pencil's properties.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the number 2 label is more easily understood by international manufacturers.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the number 2 label is a standard convention in the United States.

title: Why are we ticklish?

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the sensation of itchiness caused by a feather on sensitive skin?

options.label: A
options.text: Gargalesis

options.label: B
options.text: Knismesis

options.label: C
options.text: Pruritus

options.label: D
options.text: Itchosis

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of gargalesis?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes a desire to rub or scratch

options.label: B
options.text: It is experienced by all mammals

options.label: C
options.text: It is only experienced by primates

options.label: D
options.text: It is a type of itchiness

multiple-choice.question: What is one possible evolutionary explanation for the phenomenon of tickling?

options.label: A
options.text: To teach young animals how to swim

options.label: B
options.text: To teach young animals how to defend themselves if attacked

options.label: C
options.text: To teach young animals how to hunt

options.label: D
options.text: To teach young animals how to communicate

multiple-choice.question: What is the typical response of a person when they are tickled?

options.label: A
options.text: They become angry and defensive

options.label: B
options.text: They become still and quiet

options.label: C
options.text: They laugh and smile

options.label: D
options.text: They become sad and depressed

multiple-choice.question: According to some psychologists, what is the possible function of gargalesis in young apes and humans?

options.label: A
options.text: To teach them how to protect themselves if attacked

options.label: B
options.text: To teach them how to communicate with others

options.label: C
options.text: To teach them how to hunt for food

options.label: D
options.text: To teach them how to swim

title: How old are your ears? (hearing test)

multiple-choice.question: If you can hear 8,000 Hertz, what does it indicate about your age and hearing ability?

options.label: A
options.text: You're over 50 years old and have hearing impairment.

options.label: B
options.text: You're both alive and not hearing impaired.

options.label: C
options.text: You're 20-30 years old and have normal hearing.

options.label: D
options.text: You're under 20 years old and have hearing loss.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the tiny nerve cells called hair cells in the ear as a result of continuous exposure to noise and loud sounds?

options.label: A
options.text: They multiply and become more sensitive.

options.label: B
options.text: They remain unaffected and continue to function normally.

options.label: C
options.text: They break, bend, and get destroyed.

options.label: D
options.text: They get replaced by new cells.

multiple-choice.question: Why do high frequencies go first as we age?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the hairs tuned to low pitches are more sensitive.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the hairs tuned to high pitches are the first to encounter sound waves and experience more stress.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the brain is less capable of processing high frequencies.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the ear is less capable of detecting high frequencies.

multiple-choice.question: What is responsible for picking up different frequencies and sending the signal to the brain in the ear?

options.label: A
options.text: Hair cells

options.label: B
options.text: Inner ear

options.label: C
options.text: Outer ear

options.label: D
options.text: Brain

multiple-choice.question: Can the inner ear regenerate like other organs such as the liver or skin?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, it has the capacity to regenerate.

options.label: B
options.text: No, it does not have the capacity to regenerate.

options.label: C
options.text: Sometimes, it can regenerate, but not always.

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on the individual.

title: What if you never forgot anything?

multiple-choice.question: According to the theory of Sherlock Holmes, what happens to our memory when we clutter it with random facts and trivia?

options.label: A
options.text: We gain more memories.

options.label: B
options.text: We forget important information.

options.label: C
options.text: We develop a perfect memory.

options.label: D
options.text: We are able to learn new concepts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the hippocampus in forming memories?

options.label: A
options.text: It stores memories.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to make memories.

options.label: C
options.text: It erases memories.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no role in memory formation.

multiple-choice.question: What is consolidation, and how does it help us form new memories?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a process of erasing old memories to make room for new ones.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a process of replaying experiences in our minds to make connections between brain cells.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a process of storing memories in a physical location in the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a process of blocking out traumatic memories.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the rare condition where a person never forgets anything?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperthymesia.

options.label: B
options.text: Amnesia.

options.label: C
options.text: Alzheimer's disease.

options.label: D
options.text: Dementia.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the medical treatment that involves controlled electric shocks to the brain to erase painful memories?

options.label: A
options.text: Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).

options.label: B
options.text: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT).

options.label: C
options.text: Medication.

options.label: D
options.text: Surgery.

title: How to tame your wandering mind

multiple-choice.question: According to the neuroscientist, what percentage of the brain capacity do human beings use?
What is the brain's attention system's role in solving the problem of information overload?

options.label: A
options.text: To process information more efficiently

options.label: B
options.text: To select and direct the brain's computational resources to a subset of available information

options.label: C
options.text: To store information in long-term memory

options.label: D
options.text: To retrieve information from short-term memory

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the gap of attention when people are presented with stressful images during an experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases

options.label: B
options.text: It remains the same

options.label: C
options.text: It shrinks

options.label: D
options.text: It disappears

multiple-choice.question: What is the opposite of a stressed and wandering mind?

options.label: A
options.text: A calm and focused mind

options.label: B
options.text: A mindful mind

options.label: C
options.text: A distracted mind

options.label: D
options.text: A sleepy mind

multiple-choice.question: According to the neuroscientist, what happens to people's attention when they are offered mindfulness training during a high-stress interval?

options.label: A
options.text: It declines

options.label: B
options.text: It remains the same

options.label: C
options.text: It stays stable

options.label: D
options.text: It improves

title: How squids outsmart their predators - Carly Anne York

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why squid often swim together in shoals?

options.label: A
options.text: To hunt for food together.

options.label: B
options.text: To communicate with each other.

options.label: C
options.text: To avoid being vulnerable to predators.

options.label: D
options.text: To migrate to new habitats.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the sensory system that squid use to detect motion in the water?

options.label: A
options.text: Echolocation

options.label: B
options.text: Electroreception

options.label: C
options.text: Hair cell system

options.label: D
options.text: Lateral line system

multiple-choice.question: How do squid use their chromatophores to blend in with their surroundings?

options.label: A
options.text: By expanding the chromatophores to match the surrounding colors.

options.label: B
options.text: By contracting the chromatophores to hide the colors.

options.label: C
options.text: By reflecting light off the chromatophores to create a mirror effect.

options.label: D
options.text: By using the chromatophores to create a smokescreen.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the ink produced by squid?

options.label: A
options.text: To attract predators.

options.label: B
options.text: To communicate with other squid.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a smokescreen or a phantom form to confuse predators.

options.label: D
options.text: To mark their territory.

multiple-choice.question: What is the fastest speed that some squid species can reach using jet propulsion?

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 10 miles per hour

options.label: B
options.text: to 15 miles per hour

options.label: C
options.text: to 20 miles per hour

options.label: D
options.text: to 25 miles per hour

title: What makes you special?

multiple-choice.question: What motivated Mariana's father to send her to a summer camp in the United States when she was seven years old?

options.label: A
options.text: He wanted her to learn a new language.

options.label: B
options.text: He wanted her to experience different cultures.

options.label: C
options.text: He wanted her to make new friends.

options.label: D
options.text: He wanted her to learn how to dance.

multiple-choice.question: What was Mariana's experience like when she first met her roommate Fatima at high school?

options.label: A
options.text: She felt immediately comfortable and accepted.

options.label: B
options.text: She felt a little shy but eventually warmed up to Fatima.

options.label: C
options.text: She felt awkward and didn't know how to interact with Fatima.

options.label: D
options.text: She felt like Fatima was trying to be her friend.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason why Mariana decided to become a journalist?

options.label: A
options.text: She wanted to travel the world and tell stories about different cultures.

options.label: B
options.text: She wanted to make a difference in her community.

options.label: C
options.text: She wanted to challenge the way people think about "the others."

options.label: D
options.text: She wanted to become famous.

multiple-choice.question: What was the most difficult part of Mariana's sister's accident for her?

options.label: A
options.text: Seeing her sister in pain.

options.label: B
options.text: Dealing with the financial burden of her sister's medical expenses.

options.label: C
options.text: Dealing with the way people looked at her sister and treated her differently.

options.label: D
options.text: Losing her sister's friendship.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message that Mariana wants to convey to her audience?

options.label: A
options.text: That everyone should be the same and fit into a certain mold.

options.label: B
options.text: That being different is something to be ashamed of.

options.label: C
options.text: That being human is what makes us special and unique.

options.label: D
options.text: That we should only focus on our own differences and not try to understand others.

title: When will the next ice age happen? - Lorraine Lisiecki

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used by geologists to describe the most recent time that ice reached a huge extent, approximately 20,000 years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: The "Ice Age"

options.label: B
options.text: The Last Glacial Maximum

options.label: C
options.text: The Snowball Earth

options.label: D
options.text: The Frigid Landscape

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main drivers of massive swings in the planet's climate?

options.label: A
options.text: Changes in Earth's orbit

options.label: B
options.text: Atmospheric carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas that traps heat

options.label: C
options.text: Volcanic eruptions

options.label: D
options.text: Human activities

multiple-choice.question: Approximately every 100,000 years, what factors align to create dramatically colder conditions that last for millennia?

options.label: A
options.text: Changes in Earth's orbit and the planet's elliptical orbit

options.label: B
options.text: Changes in Earth's axis and the amount of sunlight that strikes different parts of its surface

options.label: C
options.text: Volcanic eruptions and the burial of organic matter

options.label: D
options.text: Human activities and the burning of fossil fuels

multiple-choice.question: What is expected to happen to the sea level by the end of this century if a four-degree Celsius warming persists for several millennia?

options.label: A
options.text: It will remain the same

options.label: B
options.text: It will rise by 10-30 centimeters

options.label: C
options.text: It will rise by 30-100 centimeters

options.label: D
options.text: It will rise by as much as 10 meters

multiple-choice.question: What can scientists learn from studying past climates?

options.label: A
options.text: What drives the shifts in ice that have shaped our planet for millions of years

options.label: B
options.text: How to predict the next Ice Age

options.label: C
options.text: How to control the Earth's climate

options.label: D
options.text: How to reduce carbon dioxide emissions quickly
